elements.content: The selective uptake of guests by capsules, cages, and containers, and porous solid-state materials such as zeolites and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), is generally controlled by pore size and by the dimensions and chemical properties of interior host domains. For soluble and solid-state structures, however, few options are available for modifying their outer pores to impart chemoselectivity to the uptake of similarly sized guests. We now show that by using alkane-coated gold cores as structural building units (SBUs) for the hydrophobic self-assembly of water-soluble suprasphere hosts, ligand exchange can be used to tailor the chemical properties at the pores that provide access to their interiors. For polar polyethylene glycol functionalized ligands, occupancies after equal times increase linearly with the dipole moments of chloro-, nitro- dichloro-, and dinitro- (o-, m-, and p-) benzene guests. Selectivity is reversed, however, upon incorporation of hydrophobic ligands. The findings demonstrate how self-assembled gold-core SBUs, with replaceable ligands, inherently provide for rationally introducing finely tuned and quantitatively predictable chemoselectivity to host–guest chemistry in water.
elements.clean_text: The selective uptake of guests by capsules, cages, and containers, and porous solid-state materials such as zeolites and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), is generally controlled by pore size and by the dimensions and chemical properties of interior host domains. For soluble and solid-state structures, however, few options are available for modifying their outer pores to impart chemoselectivity to the uptake of similarly sized guests. We now show that by using alkane-coated gold cores as structural building units (SBUs) for the hydrophobic self-assembly of water-soluble suprasphere hosts, ligand exchange can be used to tailor the chemical properties at the pores that provide access to their interiors. For polar polyethylene glycol functionalized ligands, occupancies after equal times increase linearly with the dipole moments of chloro-, nitro- dichloro-, and dinitro- (o-, m-, and p-) benzene guests. Selectivity is reversed, however, upon incorporation of hydrophobic ligands. The findings demonstrate how self-assembled gold-core SBUs, with replaceable ligands, inherently provide for rationally introducing finely tuned and quantitatively predictable chemoselectivity to host-guest chemistry in water.

elements.content: In numerous molecular and self-assembled capsules, cages, and containers, rates of guest uptake are controlled by the sizes of openings generated by structural linkers, and the size of the host-domain itself. In addition, chemical properties of the host domains provide thermodynamic control over the uptake of chemically different guests, based on noncovalent interactions ranging from van der Waals forces to hydrogen bonding, electrostatic effects, and halogen bonding. Guest uptake by zeolites, while famously size-selective, also includes considerations of host properties, such as structurally integral Lewis acid sites, and alkali-metal counter-cations, such as those that render the natural zeolite, chabazite, selective for CO2 over CH4. For metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), with much larger host domains and connective channels, size selectivity for small molecules is limited, but counterbalanced by other controlling phenomena such as small-molecule (e.g., H2 and CO2) condensation, in combination with the chemical properties of the host environment, the presence of Lewis acid sites, and more recently by guest-triggered conformational changes to pore geometries. With few exceptions, however, including relatively small host systems, the above structures do not inherently provide synthetically reliable options for chemically modifying outer apertures or pores to chemoselectively differentiate between similarly sized guests.
elements.clean_text: In numerous molecular and self-assembled capsules, cages, and containers, rates of guest uptake are controlled by the sizes of openings generated by structural linkers, and the size of the host-domain itself. In addition, chemical properties of the host domains provide thermodynamic control over the uptake of chemically different guests, based on noncovalent interactions ranging from van der Waals forces to hydrogen bonding, electrostatic effects, and halogen bonding. Guest uptake by zeolites, while famously size-selective, also includes considerations of host properties, such as structurally integral Lewis acid sites, and alkali-metal counter-cations, such as those that render the natural zeolite, chabazite, selective for CO2 over CH4. For metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), with much larger host domains and connective channels, size selectivity for small molecules is limited, but counterbalanced by other controlling phenomena such as small-molecule (e.g., H2 and CO2) condensation, in combination with the chemical properties of the host environment, the presence of Lewis acid sites, and more recently by guest-triggered conformational changes to pore geometries. With few exceptions, however, including relatively small host systems, the above structures do not inherently provide synthetically reliable options for chemically modifying outer apertures or pores to chemoselectively differentiate between similarly sized guests.

elements.content: In this regard, we recently reported 200 nm gold-nanoparticle (gold-NP) supraspheres (A), prepared by using the metal oxide cluster-anion ligand, AlW11O39 9– (1), to control the reaction of 4 nm gold NPs with hexanethiol (hex-SH) in water. The reaction results in the hydrophobically driven self-assembly of hex-S coated gold cores into close-packed supraspheres featuring interconnected networks of tetrahedral (T d) and octahedral (O h) host domains, and exchangeable molecules of 1 at their outer surfaces (A). Each suprasphere serves as a soluble host for over two million hydrophobic guests, a capacity rivalling those of zeolites and MOFs. While exploring that phenomenon, we found that hydrophilic polyethylene glycol thiolates (PEG-S) at the outer-pore regions of the suprapheres (lower right in A, and B) inhibited the uptake of nonpolar hydrophobic guests, while uptake of the same guests was observed for supraspheres wrapped by mixtures of hexanethiolate (hex-S) and PEG-S (C). Those preliminary findings pointed to a new type of ligand-regulated chemoselectivity.
elements.clean_text: In this regard, we recently reported 200 nm gold-nanoparticle (gold-NP) supraspheres (A), prepared by using the metal oxide cluster-anion ligand, AlW11O39 9- (1), to control the reaction of 4 nm gold NPs with hexanethiol (hex-SH) in water. The reaction results in the hydrophobically driven self-assembly of hex-S coated gold cores into close-packed supraspheres featuring interconnected networks of tetrahedral (T d) and octahedral (O h) host domains, and exchangeable molecules of 1 at their outer surfaces (A). Each suprasphere serves as a soluble host for over two million  hydrophobic guests, a capacity rivalling those of zeolites and MOFs. While exploring that phenomenon, we found that hydrophilic polyethylene glycol thiolates (PEG-S) at the outer-pore regions of the suprapheres (lower right in A, and B) inhibited the uptake of nonpolar hydrophobic guests, while uptake of the same guests was observed for supraspheres wrapped by mixtures of hexanethiolate (hex-S) and PEG-S (C). Those preliminary findings pointed to a new type of ligand-regulated chemoselectivity.

elements.content: (A) A 200 nm suprasphere comprised of ca. 27 000 hex-S coated 4 nm gold cores (SBUs), with exchangeable molecules of 1 (shown in blue) on its outer surface. Upper right is an O h hole (hydrophobic cavity) whose triangular face forms a pore of height h (lower right) that provides access to the hydrophobic interior. The black shells indicate monolayers of hex-S. (B) A triangular pore region fitted with PEG-S (via displacement of 1) and (C) a pore with “patches” of hex-S and PEG-S domains.
elements.clean_text: 1  (A) A 200 nm suprasphere comprised of ca. 27000 hex-S coated 4 nm gold cores (SBUs), with exchangeable molecules of 1 (shown in blue) on its outer surface. Upper right is an O h hole (hydrophobic cavity) whose triangular face forms a pore of height h (lower right) that provides access to the hydrophobic interior. The black shells indicate monolayers of hex-S. (B) A triangular pore region fitted with PEG-S (via displacement of 1) and (C) a pore with "patches" of hex-S and PEG-S domains.

elements.content: We now report that ligand exchange at the outer pores that provide access to the interior of supraspherical hosts comprised of self-assembled gold-core SBUs makes it possible to discriminate between differently shaped, yet similarly sized and compositionally identical hydrophobic guests. Moreover, guest occupancies vary as a linear function of their dipole moments. This unprecedented phenomenon provides a rational basis for introducing finely tuned chemoselectivity to host–guest chemistry in water.
elements.clean_text: We now report that ligand exchange at the outer pores that provide access to the interior of supraspherical hosts comprised of self-assembled gold-core SBUs makes it possible to discriminate between differently shaped, yet similarly sized and compositionally identical hydrophobic guests. Moreover, guest occupancies vary as a linear function of their dipole moments. This unprecedented phenomenon provides a rational basis for introducing finely tuned chemoselectivity to host-guest chemistry in water.

elements.content: Synthesis of the ca. 200 nm supraspheres () relies on the ability of 1 to serve as a self-reporting leaving group for controlling the reaction of gold NPs with hex-SH, allowing for their hydrophobically driven assembly while continuously imparting solubility in water to the growing assemblies. Remaining molecules of 1 can then be replaced by other ligands, such as PEG-S, to give the outer shell illustrated at the upper right in (see Figures S1–S3 in Section S1 of the Supporting Information). A cryo-TEM image of a suprasphere in its native (vitreous-water) solution state is shown in the lower right corner of .
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of the ca. 200 nm supraspheres () relies on the ability of 1 to serve as a self-reporting leaving group for controlling the reaction of gold NPs with hex-SH, allowing for their hydrophobically driven assembly while continuously imparting solubility in water to the growing assemblies. Remaining molecules of 1 can then be replaced by other ligands, such as PEG-S, to give the outer shell illustrated at the upper right in  (see Figures S1-S3 in Section S1 of the Supporting Information). A cryo-TEM image of a suprasphere in its native (vitreous-water) solution state is shown in the lower right corner of .

elements.content: Reaction of hex-SH with 1-coated 4 nm gold NPs (left) gives a gold-core SBU suprasphere (center), whose solubility in water is imparted by exchangeable molecules of 1 at its outer surface. These are replaced by PEG-S to give the structure illustrated in the upper right corner. In the lower right is a representative cryo-TEM image (scale bar: 50 nm).
elements.clean_text: 2  Reaction of hex-SH with 1-coated 4 nm gold NPs (left) gives a gold-core SBU suprasphere (center), whose solubility in water is imparted by exchangeable molecules of 1 at its outer surface. These are replaced by PEG-S to give the structure illustrated in the upper right corner. In the lower right is a representative cryo-TEM image (scale bar: 50 nm).

elements.content: In the present work, equal amounts of PEG-S wrapped supraspheres were dissolved in 1.5 mL aqueous solutions, each saturated with p-, o-, or m-dichloro- or dinitro-benzene or monochloro- or mononitrobenzene. After 7 days, the supraspheres were isolated by centrifugation and dissolved in CD2Cl2, whereupon the hydrophobic assemblies separated into individual gold NPs, simultaneously releasing the aromatic guests, which were quantified by 1H-NMR spectroscopy (Figures S4–S11, Section S2–S4).
elements.clean_text: In the present work, equal amounts of PEG-S wrapped supraspheres were dissolved in 1.5 mL aqueous solutions, each saturated with p-, o-, or m-dichloro- or dinitro-benzene or monochloro- or mononitrobenzene. After 7 days, the supraspheres were isolated by centrifugation and dissolved in CD2Cl2, whereupon the hydrophobic assemblies separated into individual gold NPs, simultaneously releasing the aromatic guests, which were quantified by 1H-NMR spectroscopy (Figures S4-S11, Section S2-S4).

elements.content: The total host-domain volume within each suprasphere, comprised of N approximately close-packed gold NPs, was calculated as the sum of the volumes of the 2N T d and N O h holes. Percent (%) occupancy of this total volume by the aromatic guests (Table S1) was determined after the seven-day reactions. Occupancy values (A) ranged from 0% for both p-disubstituted benzenes (with dipole moments of 0 D) to 47% (approaching the maximum value of 55% established by Rebek) for o-dinitrobenzene, which possessed the largest dipole moment (6.75 D). The 47% occupancy value corresponds to 3.9 million molecules of o-dinitrobenzene in each suprasphere host (Table S1). Remarkably, a linear correlation was found between the dipole moments of the eight guests and percent occupancies after the equal reaction times (A). Notably, %-occupancy values showed no correlation with substrate solubility (B), which (in principle) could affect uptake rates. Furthermore, previously reported control experiments preclude adsorption of the guest within the ca. 10 nm thick PEG layer.

The 47% occupancy value corresponds to 3.9 million molecules of o-dinitrobenzene in each suprasphere host (Table S1). elements.content: (A) Percent occupancy as a function of the dipole moments (Debye) of aromatic guests by PEG-S coated supraspheres (R2 = 0.991). Blue squares: p-, m-, o-dichlorobenzene, and chlorobenzene with respective dipole moments of 0, 1.48, 2.25, and 1.54 D. Red circles: p-, m-, o-dinitrobenzene, and nitrobenzene with respective dipole moments of 0, 3.90, 6.75, and 4.28 D. Inset: PEG-S near an external pore. (B) Guest occupancies as a function of estimated aqueous solubilities.
elements.clean_text: 3  (A) Percent occupancy as a function of the dipole moments (Debye) of aromatic guests by PEG-S coated supraspheres (R2 = 0.991). Blue squares: p-, m-, o-dichlorobenzene, and chlorobenzene with respective dipole moments of 0, 1.48, 2.25, and 1.54 D. Red circles: p-, m-, o-dinitrobenzene, and nitrobenzene with respective dipole moments of 0, 3.90, 6.75, and 4.28 D. Inset: PEG-S near an external pore. (B) Guest occupancies as a function of estimated aqueous solubilities.

elements.content: Preference for the nitro- versus chloro-substituted guests was reversed by making the ligand domains around the outer pores partially hydrophobic. This was done by replacing 50% of 1 at the outer surface of the suprasphere by PEG-S, and remaining 1 by hex-S (A). The “patchy” ligand shell (bottom of A, and C) was suggested by observed values for the uptake of the nitro-substituted guests (B).

This was done by replacing 50% of 1 at the outer surface of the suprasphere by PEG-S, and remaining 1 by hex-S (A). The "patchy" ligand shell (bottom of A, and C) was suggested by observed values for the uptake of the nitro-substituted guests (B).

elements.content: (A) Patchy domains obtained by sequential replacements of 50% of 1 (top left) by PEG-S, followed by hex-S. The patchy nature of the surface domains was indicated by the data in (B), a comparison of %-occupancies (after 7-day reaction times) of the nitrobenzene guests in supraspheres with PEG-S (green bars) and 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S (brown bars).
elements.clean_text: 4  (A) Patchy domains obtained by sequential replacements of 50% of 1 (top left) by PEG-S, followed by hex-S. The patchy nature of the surface domains was indicated by the data in (B), a comparison of %-occupancies (after 7-day reaction times) of the nitrobenzene guests in supraspheres with PEG-S (green bars) and 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S (brown bars).

elements.content: Notably, if the two ligand types formed a Janus-like (semispherical) ligand shell, rates of uptake (occupancies after 7 days) of the more polar (nitro-substituted) guests should be at least half as large as those observed with PEG-S alone. In all cases, however, %-occupancies decreased by more than 50%, suggesting that the two ligand types formed numerous smaller, partially hydrophobic island-like domains around the external pores, as shown in C (Figures S12–S18, Section S5).
elements.clean_text: Notably, if the two ligand types formed a Janus-like (semispherical) ligand shell, rates of uptake (occupancies after 7 days) of the more polar (nitro-substituted) guests should be at least half as large as those observed with PEG-S alone. In all cases, however, %-occupancies decreased by more than 50%, suggesting that the two ligand types formed numerous smaller, partially hydrophobic island-like domains around the external pores, as shown in C (Figures S12-S18, Section S5).

elements.content: With 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S, the ligand environment around the access pores is (on average) much less polar. Now, the less polar benzene derivatives (i.e., mono- and dichloro-), with dipole moments ranging from 1.48 to 2.25 D, selectively enter the suprasphere host more rapidly (blue squares in ), giving much larger occupancies than in A (for PEG-S only), while entry (%-occupancy) of the more polar nitrobenzenes (red circles in ) is correspondingly depressed.
elements.clean_text: With 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S, the ligand environment around the access pores is (on average) much less polar. Now, the less polar benzene derivatives (i.e., mono- and dichloro-), with dipole moments ranging from 1.48 to 2.25 D, selectively enter the suprasphere host more rapidly (blue squares in ), giving much larger occupancies than in A (for PEG-S only), while entry (%-occupancy) of the more polar nitrobenzenes (red circles in ) is correspondingly depressed.

elements.content: Reversal of guest-uptake selectivity by use of 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells. Red circles: nitro-substituted benzenes plotted in Figure A. Blue squares: chloro-substituted benzenes plotted in Figure A. Respective R 2 values are 0.994 and 0.998. Inset: Patchy coverage by the two ligand types near a pore at the surface of the suprasphere host.
elements.clean_text: 5  Reversal of guest-uptake selectivity by use of 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells. Red circles: nitro-substituted benzenes plotted in Figure  A. Blue squares: chloro-substituted benzenes plotted in Figure  A. Respective R 2 values are 0.994 and 0.998. Inset: Patchy coverage by the two ligand types near a pore at the surface of the suprasphere host.

elements.content: As observed for 100% PEG-S (A), occupancies varied as linear functions of dipole moments, in the present case with different responses (and two separate linear plots: ) for the less polar, chloro-substituted guests (blue squares), and more polar, nitro-substituted guests (red circles).
elements.clean_text: As observed for 100% PEG-S (A), occupancies varied as linear functions of dipole moments, in the present case with different responses (and two separate linear plots: ) for the less polar, chloro-substituted guests (blue squares), and more polar, nitro-substituted guests (red circles).

elements.content: The linear behavior observed in and is consistent with steady-state partition of the guests between water and the 1.5 nm (hex-S) to several-nm thick (PEG-S) ligand domains in the vicinity of the outer pores, in combination with approximately planar diffusion through these self-assembled monolayers. The driving force for uptake itself is provided by hydrophobic interactions with the entirely hex-S coated gold surfaces inside the supraspherical assembly. According to this model, relative rates of guest uptake appear to obey the first-order kinetics typical of diffusion through planar membranes.
elements.clean_text: The linear behavior observed in  and  is consistent with steady-state partition of the guests between water and the 1.5 nm (hex-S) to several-nm thick (PEG-S) ligand domains in the vicinity of the outer pores, in combination with approximately planar diffusion through these self-assembled monolayers. The driving force for uptake itself is provided by hydrophobic interactions with the entirely hex-S coated gold surfaces inside the supraspherical assembly. According to this model, relative rates of guest uptake appear to obey the first-order kinetics typical of diffusion through planar membranes.

elements.content: In addition to chemoselective uptake, the choice of gold-core size additionally determines the dimensions of the approximately triangular pores that provide entry into the host assembly and “percolation” of guests to interior O h and T d holes (host domains). This naturally provides options for size selectivity, analogous to that in porous solid-state materials.
elements.clean_text: In addition to chemoselective uptake, the choice of gold-core size additionally determines the dimensions of the approximately triangular pores that provide entry into the host assembly and "percolation" of guests to interior O h and T d holes (host domains). This naturally provides options for size selectivity, analogous to that in porous solid-state materials.

elements.content: This was demonstrated by preparing supraspheres from hexanethiolate-coated 2 nm diameter gold cores, with average pore heights (h) of 1.47 nm (A; see Figures S19–S24, Section S6). Notably, PEG-S and 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells gave the same chemoselectivity as that described above for the 4 nm gold core assemblies (–; Figures S25–S38, Section S7, Table S2). Using 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells, three different molecular-weight polystyrene (PS) spheres were then used as incrementally larger guests (center of ). Due to PS insolubility in water, uptake reactions were carried out in 1:39 water/DMF. Using the 4 nm gold-core assembly (h = 2.20 nm; B), PS spheres of all three sizes (i.e., 1.34, 1.62, and 2.14 nm) were found as guests after 7 days, with respective occupancies (decreasing with PS size) of 45%, 18%, and 7.6% (Figures S39–S41, Section S8, Table S3). By contrast, using the 2 nm gold-core assembly, only the smaller (1.34 and 1.62 nm) PS spheres were sequestered, with respective occupancies of 33% and 11.8% (Figures S42–S44, Section S9, Table S4).
elements.clean_text: This was demonstrated by preparing supraspheres from hexanethiolate-coated 2 nm diameter gold cores, with average pore heights (h) of 1.47 nm (A; see Figures S19-S24, Section S6). Notably, PEG-S and 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells gave the same chemoselectivity as that described above for the 4 nm gold core assemblies (-; Figures S25-S38, Section S7, Table S2). Using 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells, three different molecular-weight polystyrene (PS) spheres were then used as incrementally larger guests (center of ). Due to PS insolubility in water, uptake reactions were carried out in 1:39 water/DMF. Using the 4 nm gold-core assembly (h = 2.20 nm; B), PS spheres of all three sizes (i.e., 1.34, 1.62, and 2.14 nm) were found as guests after 7 days, with respective occupancies (decreasing with PS size) of 45%, 18%, and 7.6% (Figures S39-S41, Section S8, Table S3). By contrast, using the 2 nm gold-core assembly, only the smaller (1.34 and 1.62 nm) PS spheres were sequestered, with respective occupancies of 33% and 11.8% (Figures S42-S44, Section S9, Table S4).

elements.content: Calculated average heights (h) of outer pores and interior channels for supraspheres prepared from hex-S coated 2 nm gold cores (A) and 4 nm gold cores (B); the black shells indicate monolayers of hex-S. Inset: Diameters of three different PS spheres, shown in gray.
elements.clean_text: 6  Calculated average heights (h) of outer pores and interior channels for supraspheres prepared from hex-S coated 2 nm gold cores (A) and 4 nm gold cores (B); the black shells indicate monolayers of hex-S. Inset: Diameters of three different PS spheres, shown in gray.

elements.content: Interestingly, nonpolar PS spheres penetrated the 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells, while no uptake was observed for p-dinitrobenzene (). A tentative explanation, based on electrostatics, is that even for p-dinitrobenzene (with a dipole moment of zero), the negatively charged O atoms of each nitro group (which sum to a formal charge of −1) prevent adsorption into hex-S ligand domains, while, for 100% PEG-S (), the zero dipole moment of p-dinitrobenzene itself dominates, precluding adsorption within the polar polyether structure. By contrast, PS is entirely compatible with hex-S domains. Support for the role of electrostatics is provided by the modest uptake of p-dichlorobenzene by 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S coated supraspheres (). Like PS, p-dichlorobenzene is nonpolar, and with −Cl rather than −NO2 substituents, enters the supraspheres through pores located in more highly hex-S-rich domains.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, nonpolar PS spheres penetrated the 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells, while no uptake was observed for p-dinitrobenzene (). A tentative explanation, based on electrostatics, is that even for p-dinitrobenzene (with a dipole moment of zero), the negatively charged O atoms of each nitro group (which sum to a formal charge of -1) prevent adsorption into hex-S ligand domains, while, for 100% PEG-S (), the zero dipole moment of p-dinitrobenzene itself dominates, precluding adsorption within the polar polyether structure. By contrast, PS is entirely compatible with hex-S domains. Support for the role of electrostatics is provided by the modest uptake of p-dichlorobenzene by 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S coated supraspheres (). Like PS, p-dichlorobenzene is nonpolar, and with -Cl rather than -NO2 substituents, enters the supraspheres through pores located in more highly hex-S-rich domains.

elements.content: In summary, ligand exchange at the outer surfaces of porous water-soluble assemblies prepared from gold-core structural building units (SBUs) provides inherent options for introducing a type of chemoselectivity not readily achievable with capsules, cages, and containers, porous solid-state oxides, or metal–organic frameworks. Unprecedented control over chemoselective uptake is demonstrated by a linear correlation between host-domain occupancies at a fixed time and the dipole moments of eight chloro- and nitro-functionalized benzenes (), and by reversal of selectivity by simply changing the nature of the ligand shell from PEG-S to 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S (). This finely tuned control, understood as a nanometric scale manifestation of the kinetically first-order diffusion through planar membranes, is readily adaptable to other classes of guests by simply introducing other ligands or ligand combinations, and can be combined with traditional size selectivity by changing the size of the gold-core SBUs. The findings not only are fundamentally important to understanding and quantitatively controlling substrate sequestration but also demonstrate a conceptually new approach, in which membrane-like diffusion through tailored ligand domains is utilized to rationally control and finely tune the chemoselective uptake of similarly sized guests.
elements.clean_text: In summary, ligand exchange at the outer surfaces of porous water-soluble assemblies prepared from gold-core structural building units (SBUs) provides inherent options for introducing a type of chemoselectivity not readily achievable with capsules, cages, and containers, porous solid-state oxides, or metal-organic frameworks. Unprecedented control over chemoselective uptake is demonstrated by a linear correlation between host-domain occupancies at a fixed time and the dipole moments of eight chloro- and nitro-functionalized benzenes (), and by reversal of selectivity by simply changing the nature of the ligand shell from PEG-S to 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S (). This finely tuned control, understood as a nanometric scale manifestation of the kinetically first-order diffusion through planar membranes, is readily adaptable to other classes of guests by simply introducing other ligands or ligand combinations, and can be combined with traditional size selectivity by changing the size of the gold-core SBUs. The findings not only are fundamentally important to understanding and quantitatively controlling substrate sequestration but also demonstrate a conceptually new approach, in which membrane-like diffusion through tailored ligand domains is utilized to rationally control and finely tune the chemoselective uptake of similarly sized guests.

Upper right is an O h hole (hydrophobic cavity) whose triangular face forms a pore of height h (lower right) that provides access to the hydrophobic interior. The black shells indicate monolayers of hex-S. (B) A triangular pore region fitted with PEG-S (via displacement of 1) and (C) a pore with “patches” of hex-S and PEG-S domains.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (A) A 200 nm suprasphere comprised of ca. 27000 hex-S coated 4 nm gold cores (SBUs), with exchangeable molecules of 1 (shown in blue) on its outer surface. Upper right is an O h hole (hydrophobic cavity) whose triangular face forms a pore of height h (lower right) that provides access to the hydrophobic interior. The black shells indicate monolayers of hex-S. (B) A triangular pore region fitted with PEG-S (via displacement of 1) and (C) a pore with "patches" of hex-S and PEG-S domains.

cln_elements.content: Reaction of hex-SH with 1-coated 4 nm gold NPs (left) gives a gold-core SBU suprasphere (center), whose solubility in water is imparted by exchangeable molecules of 1 at its outer surface. These are replaced by PEG-S to give the structure illustrated in the upper right corner. In the lower right is a representative cryo-TEM image (scale bar: 50 nm).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Reaction of hex-SH with 1-coated 4 nm gold NPs (left) gives a gold-core SBU suprasphere (center), whose solubility in water is imparted by exchangeable molecules of 1 at its outer surface. These are replaced by PEG-S to give the structure illustrated in the upper right corner. In the lower right is a representative cryo-TEM image (scale bar: 50 nm).

cln_elements.content: (A) Percent occupancy as a function of the dipole moments (Debye) of aromatic guests by PEG-S coated supraspheres (R2 = 0.991). Blue squares: p-, m-, o-dichlorobenzene, and chlorobenzene with respective dipole moments of 0, 1.48, 2.25, and 1.54 D. Red circles: p-, m-, o-dinitrobenzene, and nitrobenzene with respective dipole moments of 0, 3.90, 6.75, and 4.28 D. Inset: PEG-S near an external pore. (B) Guest occupancies as a function of estimated aqueous solubilities.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (A) Percent occupancy as a function of the dipole moments (Debye) of aromatic guests by PEG-S coated supraspheres (R2 = 0.991). Blue squares: p-, m-, o-dichlorobenzene, and chlorobenzene with respective dipole moments of 0, 1.48, 2.25, and 1.54 D. Red circles: p-, m-, o-dinitrobenzene, and nitrobenzene with respective dipole moments of 0, 3.90, 6.75, and 4.28 D. Inset: PEG-S near an external pore. (B) Guest occupancies as a function of estimated aqueous solubilities.

cln_elements.content: (A) Patchy domains obtained by sequential replacements of 50% of 1 (top left) by PEG-S, followed by hex-S. The patchy nature of the surface domains was indicated by the data in (B), a comparison of %-occupancies (after 7-day reaction times) of the nitrobenzene guests in supraspheres with PEG-S (green bars) and 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S (brown bars).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (A) Patchy domains obtained by sequential replacements of 50% of 1 (top left) by PEG-S, followed by hex-S. The patchy nature of the surface domains was indicated by the data in (B), a comparison of %-occupancies (after 7-day reaction times) of the nitrobenzene guests in supraspheres with PEG-S (green bars) and 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S (brown bars).

cln_elements.content: Reversal of guest-uptake selectivity by use of 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells. Red circles: nitro-substituted benzenes plotted in Figure A. Blue squares: chloro-substituted benzenes plotted in Figure A. Respective R 2 values are 0.994 and 0.998. Inset: Patchy coverage by the two ligand types near a pore at the surface of the suprasphere host.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Reversal of guest-uptake selectivity by use of 1:1 hex-S:PEG-S ligand shells. Red circles: nitro-substituted benzenes plotted in Figure  A. Blue squares: chloro-substituted benzenes plotted in Figure  A. Respective R 2 values are 0.994 and 0.998. Inset: Patchy coverage by the two ligand types near a pore at the surface of the suprasphere host.

cln_elements.content: Calculated average heights (h) of outer pores and interior channels for supraspheres prepared from hex-S coated 2 nm gold cores (A) and 4 nm gold cores (B); the black shells indicate monolayers of hex-S. Inset: Diameters of three different PS spheres, shown in gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Calculated average heights (h) of outer pores and interior channels for supraspheres prepared from hex-S coated 2 nm gold cores (A) and 4 nm gold cores (B); the black shells indicate monolayers of hex-S. Inset: Diameters of three different PS spheres, shown in gray.

metadata.title:
Ligand-Regulated
Uptake of Dipolar-Aromatic Guests
by Hydrophobically Assembled Suprasphere Hosts
